docs.title: Course Goals
docs.text: This course examines object-oriented design and programming in greater detail. An examination of the use of the data structures provided by language-specific libraries, and some common simple algorithms. Students learn to design and implement simple applications. The emphasis of this course is on learning good design. This course is suitable for non-majors who want to improve their ability to solve problems using programs.

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Design and implement object-oriented programs in Java that integrate encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism, and interfaces.
  • Analyze and debug Java programs to trace execution, identify errors, and improve correctness.
  • Evaluate alternative design choices (e.g., composition vs inheritance, abstract classes vs interfaces) and justify trade-offs.
  • Create a medium-scale Java project that demonstrates sound object-oriented design principles.

docs.title: Declaring variables
docs.text:
A variable declaration is a statement that reserves a named space in memory to store a value. The syntax is to specify the data type followed by the variable name.

Syntax: 

dataType variableName;

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Integer:
int studentCount;
  1. String (text):
String welcomeMessage;
  1. Decimal Number:
double averageScore;
  1. Boolean (true/false):
boolean isComplete;

docs.title: Assigning values
docs.text:
The assignment statement places a specific piece of data into a variable. The assignment operator (=) is used for this purpose. You can assign a value at the time of declaration or later in your code.

Syntax: 

variableName = value;

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Combined Declaration and Assignment:
int numStudents = 25;
  1. Separate Declaration and Assignment:
String courseName;
courseName = "Computer Science II";
  1. Assigning a decimal value:
double courseGrade = 94.5;
  1. Assigning a boolean value:
boolean passed = true;

docs.title: Arithmetic operators
docs.text:
These operators are used to perform mathematical calculations.

Operator Name Example + Addition a + b - Subtraction a - b * Multiplication a * b / Division a / b % Modulus a % b

The Modulus operator is used to find the remainder. We will use this often.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Addition and Subtraction:
int sum = 10 + 5;      // sum is 15
int difference = 20 - 7; // difference is 13
  1. Multiplication and Division:
double product = 4.5 * 2.0; // product is 9.0
double quotient = 10.0 / 4.0; // quotient is 2.5
  1. Integer Division:
int result = 10 / 4;    // result is 2 (the decimal part is truncated)
  1. Modulus (Remainder):
int remainder = 10 % 3; // remainder is 1

docs.title: Expressions
docs.text:
An expression is a combination of variables, values, and operators that evaluates to a single value. Expressions can be placed on the right-hand side of an assignment statement.

Syntax: 

dataType variable = expression;

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Simple Arithmetic Expression:
int finalScore = midTermScore + finalExamScore;
  1. Expression with multiple operators:
double total = (item1Price + item2Price) * salesTax;
  1. Expression with a method call:
double circumference = 2 * Math.PI * radius;
  1. Boolean expression:
boolean isPassing = (score > 70);

docs.title: String operators
docs.text:
The primary operator for strings is the + operator, which performs concatenation. It combines two or more strings to create a new one.

Syntax: 

String newString = string1 + string2;

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Combining two string literals:
String greeting = "Hello" + " World!"; // greeting is "Hello World!"
  1. Combining a string variable and a literal:
String userName = "Jane";
String welcomeMessage = "Welcome, " + userName; // welcomeMessage is "Welcome, Jane"

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Concatenating strings with numbers:
int numItems = 3;
String message = "You have " + numItems + " items in your cart.";
// message is "You have 3 items in your cart."
  1. Building a path:
String root = "/users/";
String path = root + userName + "/documents";
// path is "/users/Jane/documents"

docs.title: Printing variables
docs.text:
You can display the value stored in a variable using System.out.println(). The + operator is used to concatenate (combine) strings with variables to create a more readable output.

Syntax: 

System.out.println(variableName);
System.out.println("Text" + variableName);

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Printing an integer:
int score = 85;
System.out.println(score);
// Output: 85
  1. Printing with a descriptive string:
String student = "Alice";
System.out.println("The student is: " + student);
// Output: The student is: Alice

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Printing multiple variables:
int count = 5;
String item = "books";
System.out.println("You have " + count + " " + item + ".");
// Output: You have 5 books.
  1. Printing the result of a calculation:
double total = 15.75;
System.out.println("The total is $" + total);
// Output: The total is $15.75

docs.title: Relational operators
docs.text:
These operators are used to compare two values. The result of a relational operation is always a boolean value (true or false).

Operator Name Example == Equal to a == b != Not equal to a != b < Less than a < b > Greater than a > b <= Less than or equal to a <= b >= Greater than or equal to a >= b

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Equality check:
int x = 10;
int y = 5;
boolean isEqual = (x == y); // isEqual is false
  1. Greater than check:
boolean isPositive = (x > 0); // isPositive is true

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Not equal to check:
String name1 = "Bob";
String name2 = "bob";
boolean notEqual = (name1 != name2); // notEqual is true
  1. Less than or equal to check:
int age = 16;
boolean canDrive = (age >= 16); // canDrive is true

docs.title: Logical operators
docs.text:
These operators are used to combine boolean expressions.

Operator Name Description && AND true if both conditions are true \|\| OR true if either conditions is true ! NOT Inverts the boolean value

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. AND (&&):
boolean isEligible = (age > 18) && (hasLicense);
// true only if age is > 18 AND hasLicense is true
  1. OR (||):
boolean isStudent = (isUndergrad || isGradStudent);
// true if either isUndergrad or isGradStudent (or both) are true
  1. NOT (!):
boolean isFinished = false;
if (!isFinished) {
    // This code will run
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Combining operators:
boolean canEnter = (hasTicket && isAdult) || isVIP;
// true if you have a ticket AND are an adult OR if you are a VIP

docs.title: Boolean variables
docs.text: A boolean variable can only hold one of two values: true or false. They are essential for storing the result of logical and relational expressions and for controlling the flow of a program.

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Storing a simple condition:
int temperature = 25;
boolean isWarm = temperature > 20; // isWarm is true
  1. Storing a complex logical expression:
boolean canRentCar = (age >= 25) && (hasValidLicense);

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Used as a flag to track state:
boolean hasSaved = false;
// ... code ...
hasSaved = true; // State is updated
  1. Directly assigning a value:
boolean isRunning = true;

docs.title: Conditional statements
docs.text:
The if statement allows a program to execute a block of code only if a certain condition is met. The if-else statement provides an alternative block of code to run if the condition is false.

Syntax:

if (condition) {
    // code to run if condition is true
} else {
    // code to run if condition is false
}

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Simple if statement:
if (score >= 90) {
    System.out.println("You got an A!");
}
  1. if-else statement:
if (age >= 18) {
    System.out.println("You are an adult.");
} else {
    System.out.println("You are not an adult yet.");
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Checking for a specific value:
String day = "Tuesday";
if (day.equals("Monday")) {
    System.out.println("It's the start of the week.");
} else {
    System.out.println("It's not Monday.");
}
  1. Using a boolean variable:
boolean isRaining = true;
if (isRaining) {
    System.out.println("Grab an umbrella.");
}

docs.title: Practice
docs.text: Even or Odd: Write a method that takes an integer as input and returns "Even" or "Odd", based on whether the number is even or odd.

docs.title: Chaining conditional statements
docs.text:
The if-else if-else chain allows you to check for multiple, mutually exclusive conditions. The computer will evaluate each if and else if in order, and will execute the first block of code whose condition is true, then skip the rest.

Syntax:

if (condition1) {
    // Code if condition1 is true
} else if (condition2) {
    // Code if condition2 is true
} else {
    // Code if all conditions are false
}

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Categorizing numbers:
int num = 0;
if (num > 0) {
    System.out.println("Positive");
} else if (num < 0) {
    System.out.println("Negative");
} else {
    System.out.println("Zero");
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Time of day:
int hour = 14; // 2 PM
if (hour < 12) {
    System.out.println("Morning");
} else if (hour < 18) {
    System.out.println("Afternoon");
} else {
    System.out.println("Evening");
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Traffic light status:
String light = "yellow";
if (light.equals("red")) {
    System.out.println("Stop");
} else if (light.equals("yellow")) {
    System.out.println("Slow down");
} else if (light.equals("green")) {
    System.out.println("Go");
} else {
    System.out.println("Invalid input");
}

docs.text: Grade Calculator: Write a method that takes a numerical grade (an int) and returns the corresponding letter grade. Use the following scale: 90-100 is "A", 80-89 is "B", 70-79 is "C", 60-69 is "D", and below 60 is "F".

docs.title: Nesting conditional statements
docs.text:
Nesting is the practice of placing one conditional statement inside another. This allows you to check for a second condition only after a primary condition has already been met.

Syntax:

if (outerCondition) {
    // Code that only runs if outerCondition is true
    if (innerCondition) {
        // Code that only runs if both are true
    }
}

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
1. Access check:
boolean isLoggedIn = true;
boolean isAdmin = true;
if (isLoggedIn) {
    if (isAdmin) {
        System.out.println("Access granted to admin panel.");
    }
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Combination with else:
boolean hasTicket = true;
int age = 22;
if (hasTicket) {
    if (age >= 18) {
        System.out.println("Entry permitted.");
    } else {
        System.out.println("Ticket is valid, but age requirement not met.");
    }
} else {
    System.out.println("No ticket found.");
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Weather conditions:
boolean isRaining = true;
boolean isWindy = true;
if (isRaining) {
    System.out.println("It's raining.");
    if (isWindy) {
        System.out.println("Bring a heavy coat!");
    } else {
        System.out.println("Just a light rain.");
    }
}

docs.title: Examples (contd.)
docs.text:
1. Complex user validation:
String username = "user123";
String password = "password123";
if (username.length() > 5) {
    if (password.length() > 8) {
        System.out.println("User credentials are valid.");
    } else {
        System.out.println("Password is too short.");
    }

    System.out.println("Username is too short.");

docs.title: Taking user input with Scanner
docs.text:
In Java, getting user input is like using a special tool called a Scanner. This tool knows how to "scan" what a person types on the keyboard.

To use this tool, you need to do two things:

1) Get the tool ready: We have to tell our program that we're going to use this Scanner tool. We do this by writing a special line at the very top of our code. 

import java.util.Scanner;

2) Turn the tool on: Inside our main program, we create the tool and tell it to look at the keyboard. We'll always use this exact line for now. 

Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);

Here, input is a variable that stores the tool. For now, think of input as a name we're giving our tool so we can call it later.

docs.title: Asking Questions and Getting Answers
docs.text:
Once you have your Scanner tool (input), you can use it to ask for different kinds of information. We'll use special commands to tell the Scanner what to look for.

Command What It Gets Example input.nextInt() A whole number (like 10 or 500) int age = input.nextInt(); input.nextDouble() A number with a decimal (like 3.14) double price = input.nextDouble(); input.nextLine() A whole line of text (a sentence) String name = input.nextLine();

docs.title: The while statement
docs.text:
int n = 10;
while (n > 0) {
    System.out.println(n);
    n = n - 1;
}
System.out.println("Blastoff!");
  • Almost reads like English!
  • The expression in parentheses is called the condition.
  • The statements in braces are called the body.

docs.title: How it works
docs.text:
• The flow of execution for a while statement is:
    1. Evaluate the condition, yielding true or false.
    2. If the condition is false, skip the body and go to the next statement.
    3. If the condition is true, execute the body and go back to step 1.
  • The body of the loop should change the value of one or more variables so that, eventually, the condition becomes false and the loop terminates.
  • Otherwise the loop will repeat forever, which is called an infinite loop.

docs.title: Be the computer
docs.text:
What will the following program print:

int n = 3;
while (n != 1) { 
    System.out.println(n); 
    if (n % 2 == 0) { 
        n = n / 2; 
    } else { 
        n = n * 3 + 1; 
    } 
}

docs.title: The for loop
docs.text:
int n = 10;
for (int i = 1; i <= n; i = i + 1) { 
    System.out.println(i);
}

for loops have three components in parentheses, separated by semicolons: the initializer, the condition, and the update.

  1. The initializer runs once at the very beginning of the loop.
  2. The condition is checked each time through the loop. If it is false, the loop ends. Otherwise, the body of the loop is executed (again).
  3. At the end of each iteration, the update runs, and we go back to step 2.

docs.title: Scope of initialized variable in for loop
docs.text:
int n = 10;
for (int i = 0; i < n; i = i + 1) { 
    System.out.println(i);
}
System.out.println(i);  // error. i is not defined

If you declare a variable in the initializer, it only exists inside the for loop.

docs.title: Correct version
docs.text:
int n = 10;
int i;
for (i = 0; i < n; i = i + 1) { 
    System.out.println(i);
}
System.out.println(i);  // this is ok

docs.title: The do-while loop
docs.text:
The while and for statements are pretest loops; they test the condition first and at the beginning of each pass through the loop.

The do-while is a posttest loop. Its useful when you need to run the body of the loop at least once.

boolean more = true;  
Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);  
do  {  
    // some business logic, such as add a transaction  
    addTransaction();
    System.out.println("Do you want to add another one.");  
    char ch = input.nextLine().charAt(0);  
    if (ch == 'N' || ch == 'n') more = false;  
} while (more);

docs.title: The break statement
docs.text:
When a program reaches a break statement, it exits the current loop.

Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);  
while (true) {  
    System.out.println("Enter amount: ");  
    int amount = input.nextInt();  
    if (amount < 0) {  
        System.out.println("Come back when you are serious.");  
        break;  
    }  
    System.out.println("Enter description: ");  
    String desc = input.next();  
    enterAmount(amount, desc);  
}

docs.title: The continue statement
docs.text:
A continue statement skips everything below it and moves on to the next iteration.

Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);  
int x = -1;  
int sum = 0;  
while (x != 0) {  
    x = in.nextInt();  
    if (x <= 0) {  
        continue;  
    }  
    System.out.println("Adding " + x);  
    sum += x;  
}

docs.title: Nested Loops
docs.text:
So far, we've used single loops. A nested loop is a loop that exists inside the body of another loop.

This is the key to working with 2D data, like grids, tables, and images.

The Concept:

For every one time the outer loop runs, the inner loop runs to full completion.

for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
    // This code runs 3 times (i=0, i=1, i=2)

    for (int j = 0; j < 2; j++) {
        // This code runs 3 * 2 = 6 times!
        // (i=0, j=0), (i=0, j=1)
        // (i=1, j=0), (i=1, j=1)
        // (i=2, j=0), (i=2, j=1)
    }
}

docs.title: The Clock Analogy
docs.text:
The most famous analogy for a nested loop is a clock.

  • The Outer Loop is the Hour Hand.

  • The Inner Loop is the Minute Hand.

The outer loop (hour hand) ticks once.

Then, the inner loop (minute hand) must complete its entire cycle (all 60 minutes).

...before the outer loop ticks again.

graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Outer: i = 0];
    B --> C{Outer: i < 3};
    C -- true --> D[Inner: j = 0];
    D --> E{Inner: j < 2};
    E -- true --> F[Execute Inner Loop Body];
    F --> G[Inner: j++];
    G --> E;
    E -- false --> H[Outer: i++];
    H --> C;
    C -- false --> I[End];

    style C fill:#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px
    style E fill:#f9f,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px
    style F fill:#ccf,stroke:#333,stroke-width:2px

docs.title: Nested Loop Example: The Grid
docs.text:
The "Hello, World!" of nested loops is printing a grid. The outer loop controls the rows, and the inner loop controls the columns.

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // We want 3 rows and 4 columns
        int rows = 3;
        int cols = 4;

        for (int i = 0; i < rows; i++) {
            // This loop body runs 3 times (once per row)

            for (int j = 0; j < cols; j++) {
                // This loop prints one row
                System.out.print("* ");
            }

            // At the end of a row, print a newline
            // to move to the next one!
            System.out.println();
        }
    }
}

docs.title: Tracing the Grid
docs.text:
Let's trace the execution. i is the row, j is the column.

i j Output 0 0 * 1 * 2 * 3 * (loop ends) (prints newline) 1 0 * 1 * 2 * 3 * (loop ends) (prints newline) 2 0 * 1 * 2 * 3 * (loop ends) (prints newline)

docs.title: Nested Loop Example: The Triangle
docs.text:
A common pattern is when the inner loop's condition depends on the outer loop's variable.

Let's print a triangle. The number of stars in each row j depends on which row i we are on.

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int size = 5;

        // Outer loop: controls the row number (1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
        for (int i = 1; i <= size; i++) {

            // Inner loop: prints 'i' stars
            // Row 1 (i=1): prints 1 star (j=1)
            // Row 2 (i=2): prints 2 stars (j=1, j=2)
            // ...
            for (int j = 1; j <= i; j++) {
                System.out.print("*");
            }
            System.out.println();
        }
    }
}

docs.text:

docs.title: The problem with variables (contd.)
docs.text:
What if we don't even know the number of students in advance?

Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);  
System.out.println("Enter the number of students: ");  
int n = input.nextInt();  
// how do we store n values now??

Answer: Use Arrays

docs.title: Array
docs.text:
• A data structure is a collection of data organized so that you can perform operations on it efficiently.
  • An array is a type of data structure that can hold multiple values under one common name.
  • Each value in an array assigned a unique number known as an index, which starts from 0.
  • A value can be accessed using the array name and index
  • Arrays are mutable (changeable), which means that once an array is created, the values of its elements can be changed.
  • Arrays must have a specified type and size (number of items that it stores).

docs.title: How to create an array
docs.text:
The syntax to declare an array is 

type[] name;

The syntax to actually create an empty array is 

name = new type[]

Example: 

int[] scores;
scores = new int[25];

  • What is the type of the elements in the array?
  • How many elements can this array store?

docs.title: Creating an array in one statement
docs.text:
Just like variables, the declaration and assignment can be done in the same statement.

docs.title: Another example

System.out.println("Enter the number of students: ");

int[] scores = new int[25];
  • How many elements can this array store?
  • We can store any number of items, even though we don't know how many, in advance.

docs.title: How to access an array location (index)
docs.text:

scores[0]; // this is the first grade
scores[24]; // this is the last grade

docs.title: Welcome to the CS2 Refresher!
docs.text:
Welcome back! This module is a quick review of two of the most important concepts from CS1: methods and objects. We'll move quickly, so ask questions if anything is unclear.

What we'll cover:

  • A deep dive into methods: parameters, return values, and overloading.

  • What an object is and why we use them.

  • Classes as blueprints for objects.

  • Constructors, fields, and instance methods.

docs.title: Reviewing Methods: The Basics
docs.text:
A method is a named block of code that performs a specific task. You can think of it as a sub-routine that makes your code organized and reusable.

Why use methods?

  • Reusability: Write code once, use it many times.

  • Organization: Break a big problem into smaller, manageable chunks.

  • Readability: Give descriptive names to blocks of code (e.g., calculateTaxes()).

docs.title: Anatomy of a Method
docs.text:
Let's look at the parts of a method definition.

public static int addNumbers(int num1, int num2) {
    int sum = num1 + num2;
    return sum;
}

  • public static: Access modifiers. We'll explore these more, but static means it belongs to the class, not an object.

  • int: The return type. It specifies the type of data the method sends back. Use void if the method doesn't return anything.

public static int addNumbers(int num1, int num2) {
    int sum = num1 + num2;
    return sum;
}

  • addNumbers: The method name.

  • (int num1, int num2): The parameters. These are variables that act as placeholders for the data the method receives.

  • { ... }: The method body. All the code that the method executes goes in here.

  • return sum;: The return statement. It sends the value back to the code that called the method.

docs.title: Parameters vs. Arguments
docs.text:
This is a key distinction.

  • Parameters: The variable placeholders in a method definition.

  • Arguments: The actual values passed to the method when it is called.

Example:

// Definition: num1 and num2 are parameters
public static int add(int num1, int num2) { ... }

// Call: 10 and 5 are arguments
int result = add(10, 5);

docs.title: The main Method
docs.text:
The main method is the entry point of every Java application. It's the first method that runs when you execute a program.

public static void main(String[] args) {
    // Your program starts here.
}

  • It must be public and static.

  • The return type is always void because it doesn't return a value.

  • It always accepts a String[] (an array of strings) as an argument.

docs.title: Methods as "Black Boxes"
docs.text:
Think of a method as a black box. You provide it with some input (arguments), and it gives you a predictable output (return value) without you needing to know how it works inside.

Example:

  • Math.sqrt(25.0): You give it 25.0, it gives back 5.0. You don't need to know the complex algorithm it uses to find the square root.

This is a core principle of programming called abstraction.

docs.title: Method Overloading
docs.text:
Method overloading allows you to define multiple methods with the same name but different parameters in the same class. The compiler determines which method to call based on the arguments' number, type, and order.

Example:

public static int add(int a, int b) { return a + b; }
public static double add(double a, double b) { return a + b; }
public static String add(String a, String b) { return a + b; }

When you call add(5, 10), the int version is used. When you call add(2.5, 3.5), the double version is used.

docs.title: The Transition to Objects
docs.text:
So far, we've focused on procedural programming. The program is a set of instructions (main method) that operates on data (variables).

Problem: What happens when our programs get bigger? We end up with long lists of methods that all operate on the same data.

Solution: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP). We combine data and the methods that operate on that data into a single unit called an object.

docs.title: What is an Object?
docs.text:
An object is a self-contained unit that has state and behavior.

  • State: The data or properties of the object. These are stored in fields (variables).

  • Behavior: The actions the object can perform. These are defined by methods.

Analogy: A car is an object.

  • State: Color, make, model, speed.

  • Behavior: accelerate(), brake(), turnOn().

docs.title: Classes as Blueprints
docs.text:
A class is the blueprint or template for creating objects. It defines the fields and methods that all objects of that type will have. You don't interact with the blueprint directly; you use it to build things.

^[Licensed by Google]

Analogy:

  • Class: The blueprint for a car. It specifies that all cars will have a color, a model, and methods like accelerate().

  • Object: A specific, physical car created from that blueprint (e.g., a "red Ford Mustang"). You can have many objects from the same class, each with its own unique state.

docs.title: Defining a Class
docs.text:
To define a class, you use the class keyword. Inside the class, you declare fields and methods.

public class Dog {
    // Fields (State)
    String name;
    int age;

    // Methods (Behavior)
    public void bark() {
        System.out.println("Woof!");
    }
}

This class defines a Dog object. Every Dog object we create from this blueprint will have a name, an age, and the ability to bark().

docs.title: Creating an Object
docs.text:
You create an object from a class using the new keyword. This is also called instantiating an object.

Syntax: ClassName objectName = new ClassName();

Example:

Dog myDog = new Dog();

  • myDog is an object variable that holds a reference to a new Dog object.

  • The new Dog() part creates the new object in memory.

docs.title: Accessing an Object's Fields and Methods
docs.text:
You use the dot operator (.) to access an object's fields and methods.

Example:

Dog myDog = new Dog();

// Set the state of the object
myDog.name = "Fido";
myDog.age = 3;

// Call a method on the object
myDog.bark(); // Output: "Woof!"

System.out.println(myDog.name + " is " + myDog.age + " years old.");
// Output: "Fido is 3 years old."

docs.title: Exercise - creating a Course class
docs.text:
• Create a Course class with the string fields code and title.
  • Add a method called print() to print these fields.
  • Create an object and assign the values "COSC130", and "INTRO TO COMPUTER SCIENCE II" to the code and title respectively.
  • Call the print() method of the object to print these fields.

docs.title: Constructors
docs.text:
A constructor is a special method used to initialize a new object. It's called automatically when you use the new keyword.

  • A constructor has the same name as the class.

  • It has no return type (not even void).

Example:

public class Dog {
    String name;
    int age;

    // Constructor
    public Dog(String dogName, int dogAge) {
        name = dogName;
        age = dogAge;
    }
}

docs.title: Using a Constructor
docs.text:
Now, when we create a Dog object, we can provide the initial values directly.

// Create a Dog object using the constructor
Dog myDog = new Dog("Fido", 3);

System.out.println(myDog.name); // Output: Fido

This is a much cleaner way to create and set up an object.

docs.title: The Default Constructor
docs.text:
If you don't provide any constructor, Java creates a default constructor for you. It's a constructor with no parameters that doesn't do anything.

public class Dog {
    // No constructor defined
    String name;
}

// In main:
Dog myDog = new Dog(); // This works!

But once you create your own constructor, the default constructor is no longer available.

docs.title: this Keyword
docs.text:
Inside a class, the this keyword refers to the current object. It's often used to distinguish between a parameter and a field that have the same name.

Example:

public class Dog {
    String name;
    int age;

    public Dog(String name, int age) {
        this.name = name; // refers to the object's name
        this.age = age;   // refers to the object's age
    }
}

This makes the code more concise and readable.

docs.title: Instance Methods
docs.text:
Methods defined inside a class are called instance methods. They operate on the specific object they are called on. They can access the object's fields directly.

public class Dog {
    String name;

    public void bark() { // An instance method
        System.out.println(name + " says woof!");
    }
}

// In main:
Dog myDog = new Dog("Fido", 3);
myDog.bark(); // Output: Fido says woof!

When myDog.bark() is called, the bark() method knows to use myDog's name field.

docs.title: Static Methods vs. Instance Methods
docs.text:
This is a common point of confusion.

  • Static Methods (static): Belong to the class, not a specific object. You call them using the class name (e.g., Math.random()). They cannot access instance fields.

  • Instance Methods (no static): Belong to a specific object. They can access the object's fields and methods. You must have an object to call them (e.g., myDog.bark()).

docs.title: The toString() Method
docs.text:
The toString() method is a special instance method that returns a String representation of an object. It's often used for debugging or printing objects.

  • Default behavior: It prints a gibberish-looking string (e.g., Dog@765f33f0).

  • Good practice: Override the toString() method to provide a meaningful string.

Example:

@Override // This annotation is good practice
public String toString() {
    return "Dog[name=" + name + ", age=" + age + "]";
}

docs.title: The toString() in Action
docs.text:
Now, when you try to print your object, you get a clean output.

Dog myDog = new Dog("Fido", 3);

System.out.println(myDog);
// Output: Dog[name=Fido, age=3]

The println() method automatically calls toString() if you pass it an object.

docs.title: Exercise: Creating a Transaction Class
docs.text:
Let's do a quick exercise to refresh these concepts.

Problem: Create a class called Transaction.

  • It should have fields for description (String), date (String), and amount (double).

  • It should have a constructor to initialize these fields.

  • override the toString method to display the transaction information in a clear format.

docs.title: Review of Object Concepts
docs.text:
• Class: The blueprint.

  • Object: An instance of a class.

  • Fields: The data (state) of an object.

  • Methods: The actions (behavior) of an object.

  • Constructor: A special method to create and initialize an object.

  • new: The keyword used to create an object.

  • this: Refers to the current object.

  • Dot operator (.): Used to access an object's fields and methods.

docs.title: Passing Objects to Methods
docs.text:
You can pass objects to methods as arguments. This is a powerful way to share and manipulate data.

Example:

public void giveShot(Dog dog) { 
    System.out.println(dog.name + " got a shot!"); 
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    Vet myVet = new Vet();
    Dog myDog = new Dog("Fido", 3);
    myVet.giveShot(myDog); // Passing the myDog object
}

docs.title: Pass-by-Value (for objects)
docs.text:
In Java, arguments are always passed by value. For primitive types (int, double), the value is copied. For objects, the reference to the object is copied.

  • If you change the object's state inside the method (e.g., dog.age = 4), the change persists outside the method.

  • You cannot change the object reference itself to point to a new object.

docs.title: What's Next?
docs.text:
This review sets the stage for core topics of this course.

  • Encapsulation: Using access modifiers (private, public) to hide an object's internal state.

  • Inheritance: Creating new classes based on existing ones.

  • Polymorphism: The ability of an object to take on many forms.

  • Interfaces: Defining a contract for a class.

These topics are the next logical steps in your journey to mastering object-oriented programming.

docs.title: Course Goals
docs.text: This course studies the design, implementation and analysis of important algorithms. Topics include lower and upper complexity bounds, algorithm analysis techniques, NP-completeness, sorting algorithms, searching algorithms, graph algorithms, divide-and-conquer algorithms, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, backtracking, probabilistic algorithms, and mathematical algorithms.

docs.title: Learning Outcomes
docs.text:
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Analyze the best-case, average-case, and worst-case asymptotic performance of algorithms using standard notations (Big-O, \(\Omega\), \(\Theta\)).

  • Construct correctness proofs for algorithms using techniques such as loop invariants and mathematical induction.

  • Compare and contrast major algorithms and data structures (such as sorting, graph traversal, and hashing) to determine their suitability for specific computational problems.

  • Apply key algorithmic design paradigms, including divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, and greedy strategies, to solve complex problems.

  • Synthesize efficient algorithms for engineering design situations and validate their performance through theoretical analysis and empirical testing.

  • Categorize computational problems into complexity classes (P, NP, NP-Complete) and identify when a problem is likely to be computationally intractable.

docs.title: Evaluation Components
docs.text:
Your course grade will be based on homework assignments, quizzes, a midterm exam, and a final exam. All components will emphasize algorithm design and problem-solving.

  • Homework Assignments: Homework is the primary vehicle for learning in this course. These sets will involve:

    • Algorithm Design: Developing efficient solutions to complex engineering problems.
    • Proofs: Providing mathematical justification (e.g., loop invariants, induction) for algorithm correctness.
    • Complexity Analysis: Determining the asymptotic bounds (e.g., \(O(n \log n)\)) of your proposed solutions.
    • Note: Submission must be through pdf files, and must be typed (not hand written). Using Markdown with LaTeX is highly encouraged to ensure clarity in mathematical notation.

  • Quizzes Quizzes are short, low-stakes assessments designed to ensure you are keeping up with core concepts. These will focus on "familiarity" tasks, such as tracing a specific algorithm (like Dijkstra’s or Quicksort) on a provided data set or identifying the complexity class of a given function.

  • Midterm Exam and Final Exam Exams will test your ability to synthesize the paradigms learned in class under time constraints.

    • The Midterm covers foundational analysis, sorting, and divide-and-conquer.
    • The Final Exam is cumulative but will heavily emphasize dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, and graph theory.

Important: All quizzes and exams will be paper-based.

docs.title: What is an algorithm
docs.text:
Algorithms are the ideas behind computer programs.

An algorithm for a program stays the same regardless of the programming language used, or the device its running on.

To be interesting, an algorithm has to solve a general, well-specified problem.

An algorithmic problem is specified by describing the complete set of input instances it must work on, and what desired properties the output must have.

docs.title: Example problem - sorting
docs.text:
Input: A sequence of \(N\) numbers \(a_{1} \dots a_{n}\)

Output: the permutation (reordering) of the input sequence such as \(a_{1} \leq a_{2} \leq a_{3} \dots \leq a_{n}\).

An instance of sorting might be an array of names, like ['Mike', 'Bob', 'Sally', 'Jill', 'Jan'], or a list of numbers like [154, 245, 568, 324, 654, 324].

There are many different algorithms that can solve the problem of sorting.

We seek algorithms which are correct and efficient.

A faster algorithm running on a slower computer will always win for sufficiently large instances, as we shall see.

Usually, problems don’t have to get that large before the faster algorithm wins.

docs.title: Correctness
docs.text:
For any algorithm, we must prove that it always returns the desired output for all legal instances of the problem.

For sorting, this means even if (1) the input is already sorted, or (2) it contains repeated elements.

Algorithm correctness is not obvious in many optimization problems!

Algorithms problems must be carefully specified to allow a provably correct algorithm to exist. Say we want to visit a bunch of places. We can find the “shortest tour” but not the “best tour”.

docs.title: Expressing algorithms
docs.text:
We need some way to express the sequence of steps comprising an algorithm.

In order of increasing precision, we have English, pseudocode, and real programming languages. Unfortunately, ease of expression moves in the reverse order.

We start by describing the ideas of an algorithm in English, moving to pseudocode to clarify sufficiently tricky details of the algorithm.

docs.title: Robot tour optimization
docs.text:
Suppose you have a robot arm equipped with a tool, say a soldering iron.

To enable the robot arm to do a soldering job, we must construct an ordering of the contact points, so the robot visits (and solders) the points in order.

We seek the order which minimizes the time (i.e. travel distance) it takes to assemble the circuit board.

docs.title: Robot tour optimization
docs.text: You are given the job to program the robot arm. Give me an algorithm to find the most efficient tour, starting from point A.

docs.title: Nearest neighbor tour
docs.text: Lets start at some point A and then walk to its nearest neighbor B first, then repeat from B, etc. until we visit all points.

docs.title: Closest pair tour
docs.text: Another idea is to repeatedly connect the closest pair of points whose connection will not cause a cycle or a three-way branch, until all points are in one tour.

docs.title: Exhaustive search
docs.text: We could try all possible orderings of the points, then select the one which minimizes the total length.

docs.title: Exhaustive search is correct
docs.text:
Since all possible orderings are considered, we are guaranteed to end up with the shortest possible tour.

Because it tries all n! permutations, it is much too slow to use when there are more than 10-20 points.

No   efficient,   correct   algorithm   exists   for   the   traveling salesman problem, as we will see later.

docs.title: Job Scheduling
docs.text: A movie star wants to the select the maximum number of starring roles such that no two jobs require their presence at the same time.

docs.title: Job Scheduling
docs.text:
Input: A set I of n intervals on the line.

Output:     What   is   the   largest   subset   of   mutually   non-overlapping intervals which can be selected from I?

Give an algorithm to solve the problem!

docs.title: Earliest Job First
docs.text:
Start working as soon as there is work available:

Accept the earliest starting job j from I which does not overlap any previously accepted job, and repeat until no more such jobs remain.

docs.title: Earliest Job First is wrong
docs.text: The first job might be so long that it prevents us from taking any other job.

docs.title: Shortest Job First
docs.text:
Always take the shortest possible job, so you spend the least time working (and thus unavailable).

Once a job is selected, remove all other jobs that intersect with it.

docs.title: Shortest Job First is wrong
docs.text: Taking the shortest job can prevent us from taking two longer jobs which barely overlap it.

docs.title: Earliest Job to Finish First
docs.text:
Accept job j with the earliest completion date.

Delete j, and whatever intersects j from I.

docs.title: Earliest Job to Finish First is correct
docs.text:
Proof: Other jobs may well have started before the first to complete (say, x), but all must at least partially overlap both x and each other.

Thus we can select at most one from the group.

The first these jobs to complete is x, so selecting any job but x would only block out more opportunities after x.

docs.title: Demonstrating incorrectness
docs.text:
Searching for counterexamples is the best way to disprove the correctness of a heuristic.

  • Think about all small examples.
  • Think about examples with ties on your decision criteria (e.g. pick the nearest point).
  • Think about examples with extremes of big and small ...

docs.title: Demonstrating correctness
docs.text:
Failure to find a counterexample to a given algorithm does not mean “it is obvious” that the algorithm is correct.

Mathematical induction is a very useful method for proving the correctness of recursive algorithms.

Another common way to prove correctness is by contradiction.

docs.title: Induction
docs.text: Recursion and induction are the same basic idea: 1. basis case - prove that the algorithm is correct for some basis case like an input of size \(n = 1\). 2. general assumption - assume that the algorithm is correct all the way for \(n = m - 1\) 3. general case - prove that if its true for \(n = m - 1\), then it is also true for \(n = m\)

docs.title: Example - Sum of exponents
docs.text:
Prove that the following formula is correct: $$ \sum_{i = 0}^{n} a^{i} = \frac{a^{n+1} - 1}{a - 1} $$

  • Base case: \(n = 0 \implies a^{0} = 1 = \frac{a^{0+1} - 1}{a-1}\) which is true.
  • Inductive hypothesis: Assume that the formula holds for all \(n\) up to \(m\).
  • Inductive step: \(\sum_{i = 0}^{m+1} a^{i}\)
  • \({} = \sum_{i = 0}^{m} a^{i} + a^{m+1} {}\)
  • \({} =\frac{a^{m+1} - 1}{a - 1} + a^{m+1} {}\)
  • = \(\frac{a^{m+2} - 1}{a - 1}\)
  • Conclusion: If the formula holds true for \(n = m\), it also holds true for \(n = m+1\). Therefore, it holds true for all \(n\).

docs.title: Proof by contradiction
docs.text: The basic scheme of a contradiction argument is as follows: - Assume that the hypothesis (the statement you want to prove) is false. - Develop some logical consequences of this assumption. - Show that one consequence is demonstrably false, thereby showing that the assumption is incorrect and the hypothesis is true.

docs.title: Example - Number of primes
docs.text:
Prove that there are infinitely many prime numbers.

  • Assume that statement above is incorrect. That is there are only a finite number of primes \(m\).
  • List the primes \(\{ p_{1}, p_{2}, \dots, p_{m} \}\)
  • Suppose we construct the integer formed as the product of “all” of the listed primes: \(N = \prod^m_{i=1} p_{i}\)
  • This integer N has the property that it is divisible by each and every one of the known primes, because of how it was built.
  • Lets consider the integer \(N+1\). It is not divisible by any of the primes \(\{ p_{1}, p_{2}, \dots, p_{m} \}\) because \(N\) is. Thus \(N+1\) is a prime itself - contradiction.
  • Therefore our assumption must be false.

docs.title: Example - Euclid's GCD algorithm
docs.text:
# a recursive algorithm to compute GCDs
# input : Non-negative integers a, b such that b ≤ a 
# output: gcd(a, b)
def euclid(a, b):
    if b == 0: return a
    else return euclid(b, a % b)

docs.title: Euclid's GCD algorithm - Proof of correctness
docs.text:
• We will prove that \(gcd(a,b)=gcd(b,r)\) where \(r = a \bmod b\)
  • Let \(a = qb + r\) where \(q\) and \(b\) are integers and \({} 0 \leq r < b\).
  • If some integer \(p\) divides both \(a\) and \(b\), then it must also divide \(r = a - qb\)
  • Thus, the set of all integers that divide \(a\) and \(b\), and the set of all integers that divide \(b\) and \(r\) are the same.
  • Choose the largest number form this set. This is the GCD.
  • Therefore \(gcd(a, b) = gcd(b, r)\)

docs.title: Homework Problems
docs.text:
The knapsack problem is as follows: given a set of integers \(S = \{ s_{1}, s_{2}, \dots, s_{n} \}\) and a target number T, find a subset of S that adds up exactly to T.

For example, there exists a subset within \(S\) = {1, 2, 5, 9, 10} that adds up to \(T\) = 22 but not \(T\) = 23.

Find counterexamples to each of the following algorithms for the knapsack problem. That is, give an S and T where the algorithm does not find a solution that leaves the knapsack completely full, even though a full-knapsack solution exists.

(a) Put the elements of S in the knapsack in left to right order if they fit, that is, the first-fit algorithm.

(b) Put the elements of S in the knapsack from smallest to largest, that is, the best-fit algorithm.

(c) Put the elements of S in the knapsack from largest to smallest.

docs.title: The RAM Model of computation
docs.text:
• Hypothetical computer called the Random Access Machine

  • Each simple operation (\(+\), \(\times\), \(-\), \(=\), if, call) takes exactly one time step.

  • Loops and subroutines are not considered simple operations. Instead, they are the composition of many single-step operations.

  • Each memory access takes exactly one time step. Infinite memory. No memory hierarchy

  • Count the number of steps an algorithm takes on a given instance of a problem. That give us the runtime in RAM

docs.title: Complexity
docs.text:
• To understand how good or bad an algorithm is in general, we must know how it works over all possible instances.

  • The worst case complexity of an algorithm is the function defined by the maximum number of steps taken on any instance of size n.

  • The best case complexity of an algorithm is the function defined by the minimum number of steps taken on any instance of size n.

  • The average-case complexity of the algorithm is the function defined by an average number of steps taken on any instance of size n.

  • Each of these complexities defines a numerical function: time vs. size!

  • Generally speaking, we will use the worst-case complexity as our preferred measure of algorithm efficiency.

  • Worst-case analysis is generally easy to do, and "usually" reflects the average case.  When we refer to complexity of an algorithm, always assume we are talking about the worst-case, unless otherwise specified!

  • Randomized algorithms are of growing importance, and require an average-case type analysis to show off their merits.

docs.title: The Big-Oh notation
docs.text:
• Best, worst, and average case are difficult to deal with because the precise details are very complicated.
    • May have bumps on some inputs.
    • Require too much detail to specify precisely, can't be done without actually implementing it.

  • It easier to talk about upper and lower bounds of the function. Asymptotic notation (\(\mathcal{O}\), \(\mathcal{\Omega}\), \({} \mathcal{\Theta}\)) are as well as we can practically deal with complexity functions.

  • \(g(n) = \mathcal{O}(f(n))\) means \(cf(n)\) is an upper bound on \(g(n)\)

  • \(g(n) = \mathcal{\Omega}(f(n))\) means \(cf(n)\) is a lower bound on \(g(n)\)

  • \(g(n) = \mathcal{\Theta}(f(n))\) means \(c_{1}f(n)\) is an upper bound on \(g(n)\) and \(c_{2}f(n)\) is a lower bound on \(g(n)\)

  • \(c\), \(c_{1}\), \(c_{2}\) are all constants independent of n.

  • The Big Oh notation ignores the difference between multiplicative constants.

    • \(f(n) = n\) and \(g(n) = 2n\) are identical in big-oh analysis

  • Furthermore, we arbitrarily choose a constant \(n_{0}\) beyond which the upper or lower bounds are satisfied. We do not care about small values of \(n\).

  • \(f(n) = \mathcal{O}(g(n))\) if there are positive constants \(n_{0}\) and \(c\) such that to the right of \(n_{0}\), the value of \(f(n)\) always lies on or below \(c.g(n)\)

- \(f(n) = \mathcal{\Omega}(g(n))\) if there are positive constants \(n_{0}\) and \(c\) such that to the right of \(n_{0}\), the value of \(f(n)\) always lies on or above \(c.g(n)\)

  • \(f(n) = \mathcal{\Theta}(g(n))\) if there exist positive constants \(n_{0}, c_{1}, c_{2}\) such that to the right of \(n_{0}\), the value of \(f(n)\) always lies between \(c_{1}.g(n)\) and \(c_{2}.g(n)\) inclusive.

docs.title: Big \(\mathcal{O}\) examples
docs.text:
• \(f(n) = 3n^{2} - 100n + 6 = \mathcal{O}(n^{2})\)

    • \(c =\)

    • \(n_{0} =\)

  • \(f(n) = 3n^{2} - 100n + 6 = \mathcal{O}(n^{3})\)

    • \(c =\)

    • \(n_{0} =\)

  • \(f(n) = 3n^{2} - 100n + 6 \neq \mathcal{O}(n)\)

Think of the equality as meaning in the set of functions.

docs.title: Big \(\mathcal{O}\) addition and subtraction
docs.text:
• Suppose \(f(n) = \mathcal{O}(n^{2})\) and \(g(n) = \mathcal{O}(n^{2})\)

  • \(f(n) + g(n) = \mathcal{O}(\_\_\_\_\_?)\)

  • \(f(n) - |g(n)| = \mathcal{O}(\_\_\_\_\_?)\)

  • \(f(n) + g(n) = \mathcal{\Theta}(max(f(n), g(n)))\)

docs.title: Big \(\mathcal{O}\) multiplication by constant
docs.text:
• \(\mathcal{O}(c.f(n)) = \mathcal{O}(f(n))\)

  • \(\mathcal{\Omega}(c.f(n)) = \mathcal{O}(f(n))\)

  • \(\mathcal{\Theta}(c.f(n)) = \mathcal{O}(f(n))\)

docs.title: Big \(\mathcal{O}\) multiplication by function
docs.text:
• \(\mathcal{O}(f(n)).\mathcal{O}(g(n)) = \mathcal{O}(f(n).g(n))\)

  • \(\mathcal{\Omega}(f(n)).\mathcal{\Omega}(g(n)) = \mathcal{\Omega}(f(n).g(n))\)

  • \(\mathcal{\Theta}(f(n)).\mathcal{\Theta}(g(n)) = \mathcal{\Theta}(f(n).g(n))\)

docs.title: Testing Asymptotic Dominance
docs.text:
\(f(n)\) dominates \(g(n)\) if \(\lim_{ n \to \infty } \frac{g(n)}{f(n)} = 0\)

This is the same as saying \(g(n) = \mathcal{O}(f(n))\)

docs.title: Dominance rankings
docs.text:
Commonly encountered functions:

\(n! \gg 2^{n} \gg n^{3} \gg n^{2} \gg n\log n \gg n \gg \log n \gg 1\)

Some more esoteric functions:

\(c^{n} \gg n^{3} \gg n^{2} \gg n^{1+\epsilon} \gg n\log n \gg n \gg \sqrt{ n } \gg \log ^{2}n \gg \log n\)

docs.title: Homework problem
docs.text:
For each of the following pairs of functions \(f(n)\) and \(g(n)\) state whether \(f(n) = \mathcal{O}(g(n))\), \(f(n) = \mathcal{\Omega}(g(n))\), or \(f(n) = \mathcal{\Theta}(g(n))\), or none of the above.

  1. \(f(n) = n^{2} + 3n + 4\) and \(g(n) = 6n + 7\)
  2. \(f(n) = n \sqrt{ n }\) and \(g(n) = n^{2} - n\)
  3. \(f(n) = 2^{n} - n^{2}\) and \(g(n) = n^4 + n^{2}\)

docs.title: Reasoning about efficiency - Selection Sort
docs.text:
def selection_sort(s):
    n = len(s)   # length of s
    for i in range(n):  # loop from 0 to n-1
        min_idx = i
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            if s[j] < s[min_idx]:
                min_idx = j
        # swap the values at indices i and min_idx
        swap(s, i, min_idx)

docs.title: Worst-case analysis
docs.text:
The outer loop goes around \(n\) times.

The inner loop goes around at most \(n\) times for each iteration of the outer loop

Thus selection sort takes at most \(n \times n = \mathcal{O}(n^{2})\) time in the worst case.

In fact, it is \(\mathcal{\Theta}(n^{2})\), because at least \(\frac{n}{2}\) times it scans through at least \(\frac{n}{2}\) elements, for a total of at least \(\frac{n^{2}}{4}\) steps.

docs.title: More careful analysis
docs.text:
The exact number of times the if statement is executed is given by:

\[ \begin{aligned} T(n) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} n - i - 1 \\ = (n-1) + (n-2) + (n-3) + \dots + 2 + 1 \\ = \frac{n(n-1)}{2} \end{aligned} \]

Thus, the worst case running time is \(\mathcal{\Theta}(n^{2})\).

docs.title: Insertion sort
docs.text:
def insertion_sort(s):
    n = len(s)
    for i in range(1, n): # loop from 1 to n-1
        for j in range(i, 0, -1): # loop from i to 1
            if s[j] < s[j-1]:
                swap(s, j, j-1)
            else:
                break

docs.title: Worst-case analysis
docs.text:
• The outer loop runs \(n-1\) times
  • In the \(i\)-th iteration of the outer loop, the inner loop runs \(i-1\) times in the worst case.
  • The total number of times the swap function is called in the worst case is \(1 + 2 + 3 + \dots + n-1 = \frac{n(n-1)}{2} = \mathcal{\Theta}(n^{2})\)

docs.title: Substring search
docs.text:
Here's a function that finds the first position of pattern (p) in text (t):

def find(p, t):
    m = len(p)
    n = len(t)
    for i in range(n - m + 1):
        matched = True
        for j in range(m):
            if p[j] != t[i+j]:
                matched = False
                break
        if matched:
            return i

docs.title: Worst-case analysis
docs.text:
• The outer loop runs \(n-m+1\) times
  • In each iteration of the outer loop, the inner loop runs \(m\) times in the worst case
  • In the worst case, the if block in line 7 runs \(m(n-m+1)\) times.
  • Typically, \(n \gg m\) so \(m(n-m+1) = \mathcal{\Theta}(mn)\)

docs.title: Sum of Series
docs.text:
• Often arise in algorithm analysis

  • Notation: \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} f(i) = f(1) + f(2) + f(3) + \dots + f(n)\)

  • Some commonly encountered summation classes:

    1. \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} i = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\)
    2. In general, \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} i^{p} = \mathcal{\Theta}(n^{p+1})\)
    3. \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a^{i} = \frac{a^{n+1} - 1}{a-1}\)

docs.title: Logarithms
docs.text:
• Frequently used in data-structure and algorithm analysis - very important to understand what they are and where they come from.
  • A logarithm is simply an inverse exponential function.
  • Saying \(b^x = y\) is equivalent to saying \(x = \log_{b}y\).
  • Exponential algorithms grow extremely fast. Hence logarithmic algorithms grow extremely slowly.

docs.title: Binary search
docs.text:
• In binary search we throw away half the possible number of keys after each comparison.
  • We only need 30 comparisons to search in an array of billion elements.
  • How many time can we halve \(n\) before getting to 1?
    • \(\lceil \lg n \rceil\) (\({} \lg = \log_{2} {}\))

docs.title: Logarithms and Trees
docs.text:
• How tall a binary tree do we need until we have \(n\) leaves?
  • The number of potential leaves doubles with each level.
  • How many times can we double 1 until we get to n?
    • \(\lceil \lg n \rceil\)

docs.title: Logarithms and Bits
docs.text:
• How many bits do you need to represent the numbers from \(0\) to \(2^i - 1\)?
  • Each bit you add doubles the possible number of bit patterns, so the number of bits equals \(\lg 2^i = i\)

docs.title: Properties of logarithms
docs.text:
• \(\log_{a} xy = \log_{a}x + \log_{a} y\)
  • \(\log_{a}b = \frac{\log_{c}b}{\log_{c}a}\)
  • \(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{i} = \mathcal{\Theta}(\log n)\)
    • This series is called the \(n\)-th harmonic number
    • If this result seems incredulous, recall the integral \(\int \frac{1}{x} dx = \log x + c\)
